comment_body.0:
Not sure if this is allowed, but I posted in the thread last week for opinions and, assuming all goes well, I'll be getting a 2013 981 Boxster S. I actually started the process on Carvana for a 2011 987 Boxster S in racing green which is my dream color, but it was not well optioned and after much deliberation, cancelled the order. This car will hopefully be my daily for a decade +, and I thought buying an older generation car with virtually no modern tech would eventually be something I regret, particularly when factoring in the cost of retrofits/upgrades. The 987 also had very few options - not even the sport chrono package.

Additionally, I have a racing yellow 987 Boxster S being shipped for a free test drive with CarMax. That car has the sport chrono package, but no suspension or exhaust options. And my wife isn't a fan of a racing yellow car :). I'll test drive it, but likely won't be buying it.

However, I saw a post on Rennlist for a beautiful Aqua Blue Metallic 2013 981 Boxster S. 21,700 miles, $43,900 and totally loaded - PASM, PSE, Sport Chrono, SportDesign steering wheel, 18 way seats, premium package, PDLS, ventilated seats and more. It's a beautiful car in fantastic condition and the owner has all service records. Like I said, I hope it goes well and I can close the deal.

A big thank you to everyone who has helped me on a several month long search!

comment_body.17:
Current Vehicle: 2017 Ford C-Max

Location: Midwest, near Saint Louis

Price Range: probably 12k max

Lease or Buy: Buy/trade

New or Used: Used

Type of Vehicle: Sedan/Coupe/Hatchback/Wagon

Must Haves: decent reliability and ease of maintenance, ~200 hp ~200 lb-ft torque, enough room to get groceries, really just slow car fun. bonus points if the car's exterior doesn't scream "race car"

Desired Transmission: Manual

Intended Use: Daily driver/grocery getter. Maybe autocross or something waaay down the line?

Vehicles I've considered: FiST/FoST (can't stand ford interiors and don't love ford's QC issues, also probably too expensive), Infiniti G35/N350Z (definitely the infiniti as it doesn't draw as much attention and has more room), Civic Si (no complaints just seemingly hard to find), Crown Vic (cheap, I like the idea of bolt on mustang parts), 90s SN95 mustangs (again I'd rather avoid having cops tail me every time I'm on the highway)

Is this your first vehicle: no

Do you need a Warranty: no but it's nice

Can you do Minor Work: yes

Can you do Major work: nothing that requires heavy lifting, don't have a garage or crane

Additional Notes: I still owe 7.5k on my C-Max but it's currently worth more than that at a like-new 38k miles.

Ideally looking for a car for my wife and upcoming newborn to be our family car. Ideally it would be reliable, safe, comfortable, etc., but also "fun" when needed in standard driving. We don't drive that much (e.g., once a week), but want it to be a fun experience when we do.

Right now, I'm leaning towards the GV70 when it gets released (assuming no red flags at that time) next year. Originally, was leaning towards the C43, but hard to justify the tradeoffs compared with the usability with a small SUV. Any other cars I should be looking into, and anything I haven't taken into consideration?

Also, big shoutout to /u/IKnowNewCars - super informative reading your responses and insights!
comment_body.23:
I hope this comment is allowed - it might be a little long.

Background: I live in the city (Washington DC) and commute about 4 miles out of the city, with a little bit of highway every day to work. On the weekends I go on some outdoor adventures when I have the time. I am 25 and enjoy packing people in the car when I can.

Situation: A family member has offered to gift me their 2019 Honda Civic EX-L Hatchback 4D. It only has 2,000 miles on it. If I chose this option I get the civic + approximately 5k cash. However, if I don't want the civic, I can take a lump sum of 25k to buy a car and keep whatever is left over for my savings account.

I am 25 years old, make ~70k a year, and am doing as much as I can to save for the future. The car is very nice and has many options included. However, I like to get out into the wilderness when I can and HONESTLY I've just always been a fan of slightly bigger cars.

Should I take the civic and 5k or buy something like a used Cherokee for around 16k? Are there any other used cars that I should look at?

I know I am lucky to be in the situation that I am but I need help because I really don't know what the right decision is.

comment_body.27:
Hey All,

I'm looking to buy my first car since graduating college (i.e. my first car I'm paying for myself) and I'd love some help!

Location: San Diego

Price range: $15-20k (though, for the right car I might stretch to $22/23k)

Lease or Buy: Buy

New or used: Used 2016 or newer - preferably just off lease certified pre-owned or at least with some assurances that I'm not buying a lemon

Type of vehicle: SUV

Must haves: Long term reliability - my hope is to buy this car and drive it into the ground.

I'd also love AWD/4x4 (though I wouldn't call it an absolute MUST) because I intend to make semi-regular ski trips to snowier climates and surf trips to Mexico where I'll encounter some nasty dirt roads. I also do a good amount of hiking and hope to potentially car camp in my new vehicle, both of which might require some offroading.

I also need a good amount of trunk space and/or roof racks for surboards, skis, golf clubs, and hockey gear.

Also, given that I expect to make pretty regular road trips in this car, I'd love decent fuel economy.

Desired transmission (auto/manual, etc): Doesn't matter

Intended use: Daily driver with frequent weekend/road trips

Vehicles you've already considered: Subaru Outback, Mazda CX-9 (or CX-5), Toyota Rav 4

Is this your 1st vehicle: Kind of? I drove a beater Toyota Sienna in HS but haven't owned a car since then (~5 years). This will be the the first car that I've purchased for myself.

Do you need a Warranty: Open to suggestions on this one

Can you do Minor work on your own vehicle: Yes

Can you do Major work on your own vehicle: No, but I'd also love to learn how to so if you suggest a car with ubiquitous parts that's not too hard to work on I'm all ears.

Additional Notes: While I do live in San Diego right now, I expect that my job will recall me back to San Francisco in the near-ish future (next 2-5 months) at which point I'll be driving this car in a colder, wetter climate as well as taking semi regular trips to Tahoe/back down to San Diego. I expect, therefore, that I'll be putting a good amount of extracurricular miles on this car through road trips if not through my daily commute.

​

Another thing to note is that I'm pretty enamored by the Subaru Outback. While I didn't test drive, I did go to a dealership yesterday (originally, to look at the Crosstrek but it's too small for my use case) and I loved the styling, size, and features of the Outback. I've heard it's pretty gutless (10ish sec. 0-60??) though, and I'm not sure if it's the best use of my money, so I was hoping for a second opinion from you all.

​

Thanks so much for your help!

comment_body.44:
Location: Suburbs of Chicago

Price range: <$10k

Lease or Buy: Buy

New or used: Used

Type of vehicle: Hatchback, station wagon, or compact SUV

Must haves: Small drivers seat (details in notes), adjustable driver's seat (preferably powered), telescoping steering wheel, decent rear visibility

Desired transmission: Automatic

Intended use: Daily Driver, not bad for a road-trip. Student lifestyle

Vehicles you've already considered: VW Golf, Mazda 3 Hatchback, Subaru Outback, Subaru Forester XT, Subaru Impreza Outback Sport, Subaru Legacy Hatch, Hyundai Elantra GT, Hyundai Accent, Mini Cooper, Honda Accord Crosstour, Toyota Matrix, Ford Focus. 2013 and older seem to be in my price range

Is this your 1st vehicle: Yes, other than family cars

Do you need a Warranty: Unsure

Can you do Minor work on your own vehicle: Yes, I can learn

Can you do Major work on your own vehicle: Maybe. Down the line, I'm interested in changing out the suspension, wheels, and tires for some cool factor and practicality. However, I'd prefer to have it running fine off the lot.

Additional Notes: I'm off to grad school in Fall 2021 (fingers crossed). I need a car to take me to class, to the beach on the weekends, and then back to visit my hometown. Most of the schools I'm looking at are in California or on the East Coast, so those might be 16+ hour drives. I may be able to fly in for short holidays but then my car would get lonely :(

Another major concern for me is that I'm only 4' 9" and not getting any taller. My biggest problem is the seat. Most seats are too deep so my knee doesn't clear the front and I need to use a pillow, which is uncomfortable and frankly embarrassing. I get a lot of shit for needing a pillow. Plus, I'm always worried the pillow's gonna slip at a bad time, causing me to loose control of the car in some way.

In the the family Acura MDX and Honda Odyssey (around 2012 or 2014 maybe?), I needed to use a pillow. In my gf's VW Jetta ~2010, I'm juuuust barely tall enough to drive it but I kind of have to sit semi-slouched in order to clear the front of the seat. I'd probably sit on a small pillow if I had to drive her car for an extended period of time. In the ~2018 Subaru Forester and 2021 Subaru Outback XT (two other family cars), I did not need to use a pillow. Obviously, this makes me lean toward Subarus but the Golf and Mazda seem cool. I know we're talking about inches of difference here but it really does matter when you're as short as I am. I just wanna be comfortable and safe!

TLDR; I'm 4' 9" so I need a car with a comfortable driver's seat and good visibility that will still fit into my student lifestyle.

Additional Notes: My girlfriend and I just moved to California from NYC, and are ready to buy our first vehicle. We are currently between the 2021 Acura RDX AWD Base package for $36,000 (negotiated price) OR the Toyota RAV4 XSE Hybrid for $35,000 (negotiated price).

RDX Pros: Luxury Car, Best in class, Turbo charged engine, better HP, better look and feel

RDX Cons: Higher price (marginal), base model (no backup warning, blind spot monitoring, base wheels), 24 combined mpg

Rav4 XSE Hybrid Pros: 40 combined mpg, fully loaded (however some of the options come standard on the RDX), all-weather floor liners, holds value better than any other car brand

Rav4 XSE Hybrid Cons: Less HP, Don't love the blue stitching on the interior, less prestige

I'm having trouble deciding, so I'd love to know if you all would rather get the RDX or Rav4 XSE Hybrid. My situation is that I'll be living in Los Angeles where you can tend to spend a lot of time in your car.

Thanks!

New or used: Yes?

Type of vehicle: Truck

Must haves: 4x4, crewcab, Android Auto, Tow package

Desired transmission: Auto

Intended use: Mostly daily driver, will be used to haul lumber on occasion, tow a small enclosed utility trailer a few times a year. Would be nice to have the capability to tow my 2001 S4 once or twice a year. Might eventually dabble in some light offroading/overlanding.

Vehicles you've already considered: 2016+ F150 XLT Sport w/ Ecoboost, or the 2016+ Toyota Tacoma DoubleCab TRD (Sport/Offroad/Pro)

Is this your 1st vehicle: lol... no

Do you need a Warranty: No, but I'm not opposed.

Can you do Minor work on your own vehicle: Yes

Can you do Major work on your own vehicle: Yes, but I have a shop nearby that I go to when I don't have the time/tools.

Additional Notes: Coming from a 2014 Audi Q5 3.0T S-Line package. I really like the styling of the Tacoma, and realistically a Tacoma fits in my garage whereas an F150 wouldn't. F150 feels like a lot more truck than I need, but I know a Tacoma isn't as capable as an F150. Looking for input on the two and whether there's anything else I should be considering when making this decision.

I currently drive a 2002 GMC Sierra pickup truck with 325,000 miles, RWD, shitty tires, garbage gas mileage and a cracked winshield, I'm getting real fucking sick of it and I want something smaller and more manuverable plus something that isn't garbage in the snow. I've been looking at Subaru wagons and I really like the look of the 1st and 2nd gen foresters, and the 1st gen CR-V, every one I'm looking at has like 200,000+ miles and I don't want something that high mileage. anything else I should be looking at? I also looked at a volvo xc90 and frankly didn't like how it drove.

comment_body.81:
Location: USA, SE Michigan

Price range: $25-35k (invoice price) - or depending on the invoice price/residual/money factor of the lease, somewhere around $400/mo over 36 months.

Lease or Buy: Lease

New or used: New

Type of vehicle: Truck, Crossover, Car, SUV (I know...bear with me)

Must haves: Cargo space, interior quality, good resale (i.e. better residual cost), prefer Apple CarPlay, prefer good fuel economy, prefer smooth ride, AWD nice-to-have (Michigan winters)

Desired transmission (auto/manual, etc): Auto

Intended use: Daily driver

Vehicles you've already considered: Honda Ridgeline, Subaru Outback, Jeep Wrangler, Audi Allroad, Toyota Tacoma, VW Golf SportWagon

Is this your 1st vehicle: No

Do you need a Warranty: New car, lease, presumably comes with one?

Can you do Minor work on your own vehicle: No

Can you do Major work on your own vehicle: No

Additional Notes:

  • Coming from a 2018 Honda Fit lease. Liked the excellent cargo space. Car was unfussy, never caused problems, Apple CarPlay was nice. Honda Magic seats always came in handy. CVT sucked at times, but not experienced with cars to have strong opinions like some do. I quite liked the car, but ready for a change.
  • Classic millennial setup: two adults, no kids, dog that takes up the whole back row, spoiled rotten. When we go camping or take trips, we really pushed the Honda Fit to its limits. 3h+ drives got uncomfortable for passengers and pup alike.
  • Crossovers/SUVs in general don't appeal to me. I prefer the old, boxy SUVs which aren't so common nowadays. I'm intrigued by the new Broncos, but not available on lots yet. Plus friends who work at Ford say wait until it's mid-cycle. I mostly find SUVs same-y, but open to be convinced otherwise. My biggest no-no is those SUVS that seem to actually offer less space than my existing tiny Honda Fit.
  • I don't like big for big's sake. While I'm not a truck guy, I'm intrigued by the the Ridgeline. It seems like a truck for non-truck guys. As younger homeowners we do the occasional Home Depot/IKEA/Facebook Marketplace run, and having a truck bed would stop us calling friends/renting Uhauls. Also would help for our camping trips. Tacoma seems fine too, but overwhelming options and sounds like the Ridgeline is a more comfortable daily drive.
  • As a European ex-pat in the US, I have some soft spot for Wagons that'll give me the cargo space I desire. Subarus/VWs/Audis don't seem to give much bang for buck and their relative rarity may make shopping harder.
  • Like many people, I think Wranglers and Gladiators look cool, but I hear the ride quality is pretty terrible for the price.
  • I like the idea of electric cars (could stretch to a Model 3?), but the charging still seems impractical to me.
  • In case it comes up: I'm comfortable with a lease. I do okay, I like shopping for a new car every three years, finances are otherwise in order. I've budgeted for it.
comment_body.82:
First, you should pick a car that is suitable or good for you, a coupe, an SUV or a pickup you know!

Secondly, depends on your budget!

And then the brand!!
